articles.author: Farhad Manjoo
articles.title: Only You Can Prevent Dystopia
articles.description: How to survive the internet in 2020. (It’s not going to be easy.)
articles.content: Virality was once the delightful miracle of a networked age; youd see a funny video going around, get caught up in the collective wonder and hilarity, and forward it on to your 100 closest pals. At its meme-ified best, participating in this sort of viral feas… [+2029 chars]

articles.title: 20 Books We’re Watching For in 2020
articles.description: Political memoirs, debut novels, long-awaited follow-ups: Here’s what we’re looking forward to reading this year.
articles.content: Two fathers, one Palestinian and the other Israeli, are bound together by grief: Ramis daughter was killed at age 13 by a suicide bomber, while Bassams daughter was shot dead by the border police near her school. McCann, who won the National Book Award for hi… [+1326 chars]

articles.title: The tech that will invade our lives in 2020
articles.description: The 2010s made one thing clear: Tech is everywhere in life.
articles.content: Tech is in our homes with thermostats that heat up our residences before we walk through the door. Its in our cars with safety features that warn us about vehicles in adjacent lanes. Its on our television sets, where many of us are streaming shows and movies … [+6295 chars]

articles.author: Emma G. Fitzsimmons
articles.title: More People Are Dying on New York City’s Streets. What Went Wrong?
articles.description: More cyclists were killed last year than in any year in two decades. Safety groups are calling on Mayor Bill de Blasio to  strengthen his efforts.
articles.content: But pedestrian deaths, which account for the largest share of traffic fatalities, have been a difficult problem in a city where many people walk everywhere. The deaths increased to 122 in 2019 from 115 in 2018. The fatalities included a pedestrian who was hit… [+1346 chars]

articles.author: Richard Sandomir
articles.title: Woody Vasulka, Whose Video Art Extended Boundaries, Dies at 82
articles.description: He deftly manipulated electronic images to produce otherworldly, sometimes jarring visions. He also founded, with his wife, a landmark performance space.
articles.content: Through constant electronic transmutation, every ghostly image becomes a malleable sculptural form that morphs into the next to achieve a poignant and ultimately tragic memory theater, Gene Youngblood, the author of Expanded Cinema (1970), an early examinatio… [+1207 chars]

articles.author: Anthony Tommasini
articles.title: Review: Anna Netrebko Rings in the Year With a Met Gala
articles.description: The company’s prima donna showed off her past, present and future artistry in acts from three Puccini operas.
articles.content: The Met went all out for the occasion by providing strong casts for all three acts, and Mr. Nézet-Séguin, who just had a triumph in Bergs Wozzeck a few days ago, in the pit. Ms. Netrebkos Calàf in Turandot was her husband, the tenor Yusif Eyvazov, who recentl… [+1799 chars]

articles.author: Shalini Venugopal Bhagat
articles.title: Fazle Abed, Founder of a Leading Relief Agency, Dies at 83
articles.description: Mr. Abed gave up a job as a senior executive at a multinational company to start BRAC after he saw his native land, Bangladesh, devastated by war.
articles.content:
The organization later expanded into education, and by the mid-1990s it ran more than 34,000 schools across Bangladesh. Today more than 11 million children have graduated from BRACs schools.
Mr. Abed won a number of international awards for his humanitarian … [+1258 chars]

articles.title: Trump Bet He Could Isolate Iran and Charm North Korea. It’s Not That Easy.
articles.description: The president assumed that economic levers would guide their national interests. Now, he confronts twin challenges in an election year.
articles.content:
But he made key mistakes. He failed to get a nuclear freeze agreement from the North in return for the meeting, meaning that the countrys nuclear and missile production churned along while the two old adversaries returned to their old stances.

articles.author: Donald G. McNeil Jr.
articles.title: New Injection Method Makes an Old TB Vaccine Far More Powerful
articles.description: Giving the vaccine intravenously to monkeys provided 90% protection against tuberculosis. More testing is needed before humans can be inoculated that way.
articles.content:
The Nature study tested different ways to deliver the BCG vaccine to six groups of rhesus macaques, which are even more susceptible to TB than people. 
The first group got the standard dose by the normal skin injection route, a second got a much stronger dos… [+1290 chars]

articles.author: By Denise Grady
articles.title: A.I. Is Learning to Read Mammograms
articles.description: Computers that are trained to recognize patterns and interpret images may outperform humans at finding cancer on X-rays.
articles.content:
To apply artificial intelligence to the task, the authors of the Nature report used mammograms from about 76,000 women in Britain and 15,000 in the United States, whose diagnoses were already known, to train computers to recognize cancer.
